title: Georgetown Students Vote to Add Fee for Slavery Reparations to Tuition
text:
Students stand near the glass wall to give out voter registration forms on April 11, 2019 in Washington, D.C. Mark Wilson/Getty Images
Georgetown students voted late Thursday night to add the national government to the school’s tuition structure so that students studying history would be eligible for a government grant made available to underwrite the university’s tuition structure. The vote put the issue of Slavery Reparations onto the Hoya’s annual form for taking part in the university, and two years ago, the question of the nature of that grant, as well as the schools’ arrangements with undergraduate courses, was among the factors that prompted Hoya students to make their voices heard. Georgetown’s higher education system is one of the richest in the country, and for one reason or another, it has traditionally attracted people of privilege. A recent study showed that only 1 percent of Hoya students fall into one of these socioeconomic classes, but 4 percent of them belong to the 33 percent of students who identify as White or Black. The problem with some of the larger ideas expressed in the Declaration of Independence is that there aren’t any “others.”
Blacks aren’t visible on Georgetown’s door and have been disenfranchised. To date, only one person of color has been appointed to a federal judgeship. None are on the Supreme Court, the Library has decreased its diversity over the past decade, and the university is barely making connections with the other races of undergraduate students. Georgetown’s diversity problem is compounded by the fact that most of the classes it houses are underrepresented minorities. This means that it sends the most mixed messages to White students, academics, and students of color. Because Georgetown’s structure is structured as a kind of GI Bill of rights, students at the university receive benefits to access college regardless of their race. Even its classes are designed as largely white—like both the first and second graders who work on a summer learning program. While Georgetown’s Office of History has implemented some efforts, there is much work that needs to be done. Its curriculum is diverse in one aspect: It covers contemporary slave narratives in historical form, but not slave narratives written in history. While learning about colonial history can be socially empowering, it also can cause students to engage in racist narratives, and some of them are easily overlooked or taken for granted when they do so. One of the ways that Georgetown is not ready to tackle these issues is because it is built on an institutionalized bias against First World countries and has ample racial biases. The fact that the University has student organizations dedicated to the Black, Native American, Chicano, and Indigenous struggles illustrates Georgetown’s need to consider its institutionalized bias. While black students have at least two things their University can offer them: access to higher education and a voice in the United States Congress, the institution can’t afford to do both. We can’t continue to sustain an institution that wants to honor the rights of slaves by acknowledging its institutionalized racism. This means that Georgetown’s Board of Trustees, who receive almost all of their money from the government, are working to become the anti-Columbia for political reasons. Teaming up with Columbia, who attempted to make a significant political impact with their legacy of setting the racial discussion on campus, is a way for Georgetown to be the fountainhead of progressive activism. One of the most important questions that Georgetown currently faces is how to deal with the consequences of failing to deal with race and inequality. If the campus decides to try to change its current structure, Georgetown can keep its current structure, but it can’t allow its structural biases to be exposed to the outside world.
